data.name: richTextBox1.Text
data.value: 0:00 So for the last few days, 0:02 I've been thinking about one question 0:04 that a viewer asked last week. 0:05 And it's the question, 0:07 how do I stop translating in my head? 0:10 Sometimes when you're learning a language like English, 0:13 when you hear something or read something, 0:15 the first thing you do is 0:17 you try to translate it in your head, word for word, 0:20 so that you can understand what you've read 0:22 or what you've heard. 0:23 And this just isn't efficient, 0:25 it takes so much time to translate. 0:28 And if you're having a conversation, 0:30 it can be kind of awkward 0:32 because after someone says something to you in English, 0:35 you pause for a bit while you translate in your head. 0:38 So, in this English lesson, 0:39 I'm going to look at a few different ideas and techniques. 0:42 I'm going to look at a few things that you can do 0:45 to stop translating in your head, 0:47 when you hear English or when you read it. 0:49 (upbeat music) 0:55 One thing that I would recommend 0:57 is that you do something called overloading. 0:59 Overloading is when you do more than one thing 1:01 at the same time, 1:02 and when you're learning a language, 1:04 it can be good to read while you're listening. 1:08 So, if you can find a book to read #1 - Overloading 1:10 and if you can find the audio book, 1:12 you can read the book while you're listening to it. 1:15 What this does is it makes your brain very, very busy 1:19 and you don't have time to stop and translate. 1:22 You might not understand everything you're reading 1:25 but that's okay for this activity. 1:28 The other thing it does is that 1:30 you don't get to set the speed 1:33 at which you are reading and listening to the English. 1:36 As you play the audio, 1:37 you're forced to go at the speed of the audio, 1:41 so stopping feels like something that you're not able to do. 1:44 So, overloading is a technique where 1:47 you do two things at the same time, 1:48 usually reading and listening 1:50 and it just makes your brain really really busy 1:53 and unable to stop and translate. 1:56 Again, you might not understand everything 1:59 you're reading and hearing, 2:00 but if you choose a book that's at the right level 2:04 for where you're at in learning English, 2:07 I think this technique will help you a lot. 2:10 Another thing you can do to stop translating in your mind 2:13 is to oversaturate part of your day with English, 2:16 or do what I would call long listening. 2:19 When you listen to a song, it's short 2:21 and hopefully you're able to understand some of it, 2:24 but when you listen to a podcast 2:26 or when you listen to an audio book, 2:28 it's usually a lot longer, 2:30 it might be an hour or an hour and a half. 2:33 When you do long listening, 2:35 your brain gets a little bit tired 2:38 and you might forget at some point 2:40 to actively translate in your mind. 2:43 If what you're listening to is at 2:46 or close to your level of what you can understand, 2:49 eventually your brain will just quietly stop translating, 2:53 and you'll sort of understand what's happening. 2:56 I can remember the first time this happened to me, 2:58 I'm a French learner, 2:59 and one time I was watching a French TV show, #2 - Oversaturating 3:02 a number of years ago, 3:04 and all of a sudden I realized that 10 minutes had gone by 3:08 and I had understood most of what had happened 3:11 and I hadn't translated anything in my mind. 3:14 So, another thing you can try is to oversaturate part 3:17 of your day, or do some long listening, 3:20 do something like that where at some point, 3:22 you kind of forget that you're listening to English 3:26 and your brain might automatically start to just understand 3:29 what you're hearing. 3:31 Another technique to stop translating in your mind 3:33 is called forced description, 3:36 or as I like to call it, talking to yourself. Forced Description 3:39 This is when you sit somewhere, like on a park bench, 3:42 or maybe just sit at a mall or at a restaurant, 3:45 and you describe what you're seeing 3:47 either in your mind quietly or out loud, 3:50 if you're comfortable doing that. 3:52 And you force yourself to only use words you know, 3:56 so you look around you and if you see a man with a dog, 3:59 you say, I see a man with a dog. 4:02 If you see a man with some other kind of animal 4:04 and you don't know the name of it, 4:06 you just don't describe that thing. 4:08 So, what you're doing is you're forcing yourself 4:11 to use the words you already know, 4:14 so memorizing a lot of vocabulary is obviously 4:17 a good idea as well, but don't try to describe things, 4:21 if you don't know the words. 4:23 This forces you to use the words you know, 4:25 to think in English, 4:27 and to not translate at all 4:29 while you're describing your surroundings. 4:31 Another really cool technique that you can use 4:33 is something called shadowing. 4:36 This is where you watch a video or listen to something, Shadowing 4:39 and after the person says something, 4:41 you hit pause and you say it yourself out loud. 4:44 This is mostly meant 4:46 to help you practice your pronunciation. 4:48 But it has an interesting side effect as well, 4:51 because you're listening to English 4:52 and then saying it out loud immediately, 4:55 and then hitting play and listening 4:57 and then pause and saying it out loud, 4:59 you actually stop translating in your mind 5:02 while you're doing it. 5:03 Because you're focusing on listening and pronunciation, 5:06 you forget to translate. 5:09 So again, you might not 100% understand everything 5:13 the person is saying, 5:14 you might only understand 70 or 80% of it, 5:18 but because you're busy listening and speaking, 5:21 you forget to translate while you're doing it, 5:23 which is a good thing. 5:24 So I just mentioned that knowing 5:26 a lot of vocabulary is a good idea, 5:28 there's a technique though that you can use 5:31 while learning vocabulary 5:32 which will help you to stop translating in your mind, 5:35 and it's called visualization. 5:38 When you learn a new word in English, Visualization 5:40 if you are able to try to picture 5:43 the meaning of that word in your mind, 5:45 instead of learning the equivalent word 5:48 in your own language. 5:49 This is a very powerful technique, 5:52 it helps you to distance yourself from your own language, 5:56 and it helps you to start thinking in English. 5:59 So, if you learn a new word like dump truck, 6:02 try to picture a dump truck in your mind, 6:04 or look up a picture of a dump truck on the internet, 6:08 or even draw a little picture of a dump truck. 6:11 When you memorize the word in English 6:14 and then the word in your own language, 6:16 you're almost forcing yourself to translate in your mind 6:20 whenever you hear that word. 6:21 But if you can learn words 6:23 and if you are able to visualize the meaning, 6:26 it will help you to stop translating in your mind. 6:29 As soon as you possibly can 6:31 on your English learning journey, 6:33 you should get an English only dictionary. 6:36 A dictionary where you can find the word in English Get An English Only Dictionary 6:38 and the definition, 6:40 and if you don't have an actual dictionary, 6:42 use an online dictionary that is English only. 6:45 When you first start learning a language, 6:47 it's nice to have a French English dictionary, 6:49 or a Japanese English dictionary, 6:51 they're very helpful because you can look up 6:54 what a word means in your own language, 6:56 but they are actually not a good idea 6:58 once you've reached a certain level, 7:01 because when you do that, 7:02 you're actually training your brain 7:04 to translate all the time. 7:06 So, as soon as you possibly can, 7:08 get an English only dictionary, 7:10 or if you don't wanna buy an actual dictionary, 7:12 there are plenty of English only dictionaries online, 7:16 start using that as soon as you possibly can 7:19 in your English learning journey. 7:21 So, you might be thinking to yourself 7:22 if you've been watching my video lessons for a while that, 7:26 I've said all these things before and you would be correct. 7:29 I've said most of what I've said in this video, 7:31 in other videos, 7:33 but I'm saying it again because repetition, 7:36 doing things over and over again Repetition 7:38 or hearing things over and over again, 7:40 is part of the learning process. 7:42 It's just kind of how humans work. 7:44 It would be awesome, 7:45 if you could just know something after reading it once 7:48 or hearing it once, 7:49 but it doesn't always work that way. 7:51 So, repetition is one of the last recommendations 7:55 I'm going to give you. 7:56 In order to stop translating in your mind, 7:58 if you reread things, 8:00 or if you listen to something over and over again, 8:03 eventually your brain stops actively translating it. 8:08 Eventually you'll understand what you're hearing 8:11 without your brain needing to convert it 8:13 into your own language, so do that. 8:15 If you can reread something, 8:17 if you can listen to something over and over again, 8:19 do it, add repetition into your learning. 8:22 Hey, thanks so much for watching this little English lesson 8:25 about how to stop translating in your mind 8:27 when you're reading English or listening to English, 8:30 I hope it helped you a little bit. 8:32 Once again, if this is your first time here, 8:34 don't forget to click that subscribe button 8:36 and give me a thumbs up 8:37 if this video helped you learn a little bit of English. 8:39 And if you have the time 8:41 and you don't know what to do next, 8:43 why don't you stick around and watch another English lesson. 8:46 (upbeat music)
